column4: Agifws: You can't usually mount in user mode, you have to be able to enter root mode.
Agifws: Unless that's been granted by root.  The classic example of that is mounting a cdrom or other removable media.
ths is what has happened  mount: special device /dev/disk/by-uuid/00ECF459ECF44A84 does not exist
Try: ls /dev/disk/by-uuid
07548e20-a2d3-4ec6-806f-0e4c0e78a0eb  ab82ab50-e6ba-4580-92b4-0ed4b4890b5d  457F-37F1  whats that
let me see
yes there is a dir /media/hdb5 now how do i mount ?
You misunderstood.
You need a blank directory somewhere to mount to.  Just create a directory wherever you want it to be.
Right, if I'm reading that right...
Which isn't guaranteed.
It'd be the other way around in that case, with the device as /dev/hdb5.
Try: sudo mount -t fat32 /dev/hdb5 /media/hdb5
it worked
now  when i try to copy files  to it   it says permison dinied can you help me on this one ?
Sorry, two conversations...
You'll need an extra tag in the mount line.
Start off by doing umount on the directory you just mounted to.
And then use the same mount command as before, but make it start out: mount -w -f ...
Try it.
You'll probably need to sudo umount /media/hdb5 first, though.
still not letting me
